results.title: Veterans of the road
results.creator_credit: Esso Petroleum and Veteran Car Club of Great Britain
results.brief_description: Tells the lighthearted story of a Veteran Car Club Rally of vintage cars, held at Abingdon, in Berkshire. Of quaint appearance (none of a later vintage than 1916) and still lively performance, they are seen being submitted to tests of speed, braking and steering, to the delight of many onlookers.

results.title: Veteran cars in Australia
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Thompson, Cine Service and H Sleigh
results.brief_description: In 1956 Victoria staged its Annual Veteran Car Rally over a two day period and required cars to journey from Melbourne to Ballarat and back again. Among competing cars was a 1906 Argyle, 1908 Fiat, 1914 Napier and 1914 Standard. A Cadillac built in 1913 was declared the outright winner. The annual rally provided owners of old cars to show the public the steadiness, dependability and elegance of their automobiles. Narrated by Ray Chapman.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Geoffrey Thompson, Cine Service and H Sleigh

results.title: Vesalius, founder of modern anatomy
results.creator_credit: Thomas R. Forbes, Yale University School of Medicine and Susan Wheeler
results.brief_description: Documentary on Andreas Vesalius, born in 1514 in Brussels. Appointed Professor of Anatomy at Padua in 1536, he revolutionised anatomy with clear and succint lectures and dissections of cadavers. In 1543 his seven books on the structure of the human body was published - a comprehensive work which describes bones, muscles, blood vessels, nervous system, abdominal and thoracic viscera and head. The work corrected anatomical myths dating back to Roman times and emphasised the wholistic structure of the body. His use of detailed illustrations and emphasis on dissection and observation paved the way for modern anatomy and physiology.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Thomas R. Forbes, Yale University School of Medicine and Susan Wheeler

results.title: Very good friends
results.creator_credit: Martin Tahse, Richard Bennett, Learning Corporation of America and Martin Tahse Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Learning to be human”.
Based on the novel “Beat the Turtle Drum” by Constance Greene. Deals with a thirteen-year-old girl’s reactions to the death of her younger sister, to whom she was very close. Starring Melissa Sue Anderson, Katy Kurtzman.

results.title: Vertical spindle moulding machine
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Woodworking machinery series”
Short description of machine, moulding and rabbeting stiles, rails and bar of sash. Setting the cutters, use of face board. Franking, cutting tenons to length. Other uses, the Whitehall cutter block, French or slotted head.

results.title: Vertical
results.creator_credit: David Hall and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: Both a simple catalogue of verticals and a series of visual paradoxes exploring illusions of straightness and squareness and the notion of frame. A stimulus film showing recurrence of geometrics in nature. No dialogue.

results.title: Versailles: the palace of the sun
results.brief_description: Presents the man-made beauties of the Palace of Versailles, built for the “Sun-King”, Louis XIV. Shows the famous Hall of Mirrors. Lingers on the many works of sculpture and shows the Trianons, the Queen’s Hamlet, and the great gardens designed by La Notre.

results.title: Versailles
results.brief_description: Beautiful Versailles perpetuates the history of France. This silent film with English intertitles includes a brief look at the 17th century Palace of Versailles, its history and its architecture.
